title: الإِدْغَام
description: Learn about الإِدْغَام (letter assimilation) in Arabic, including الإدغام الكبير (major assimilation) and الإدغام الصغير (minor assimilation), and the rules governing when letters merge.

notes.title: What is الإِدْغَام?
content: الإِدْغَام (assimilation) is the merging of two letters into one doubled letter (مُشَدَّد). It occurs when two similar or homorganic letters come together. The first letter becomes silent (سَاكِن) and merges into the second, which becomes doubled.

For example, مَدْدَ becomes مَدَّ (he extended). The two dals merge into one doubled dal. This phonetic process makes pronunciation easier and is a fundamental feature of Arabic morphology and Quranic recitation (tajweed).
keyPoints: الإدغام = merging two letters into one شَدَّة
First letter becomes ساكن, merges into second

notes.title: الإِدْغَام الصَّغِير
content: الإِدْغَام الصَّغِير (minor assimilation) occurs when the first of two identical or similar letters is already سَاكِن (vowelless). This is the more common type. Example: مِنْ نَارٍ → مِنَّارٍ in connected speech.

This type is 'minor' because only one step is needed: the ساكن letter merges directly. It commonly occurs at word boundaries in speech and Quranic recitation, and within words in morphological patterns.
keyPoints: الصغير: first letter is already سَاكِن

notes.title: الإِدْغَام الكَبِير
content: الإِدْغَام الكَبِير (major assimilation) occurs when the first letter is مُتَحَرِّك (voweled) and must first be made سَاكِن before merging. This requires two steps: (1) removing the vowel, (2) merging the letters.

This is 'major' because it involves more change. Example: جَعَلَ لَكَ becomes جَعَلَّكَ when assimilated (the ل of جَعَلَ loses its fatha). This type is less common in standard speech but appears in some Quranic readings (قِرَاءَات).
keyPoints: الكبير: first letter is مُتَحَرِّك (has vowel)

examples.english: He made for you (in some readings)

notes.title: Letters that Assimilate
content: Assimilation occurs between المِثْلَانِ (identical letters): ب+ب، ت+ت، etc. It also occurs between المُتَقَارِبَانِ (letters close in articulation point): ت+د، ذ+ظ، and المُتَجَانِسَانِ (letters sharing the same articulation point but differing in quality): ط+ت.

In Quranic tajweed, certain letters assimilate into others: ن الساكنة assimilates into ي، ر، م، ل، و، ن (يَرْمَلُون). These are called حُرُوف الإِدْغَام. Understanding these categories is essential for proper recitation.
keyPoints: حروف يَرْمَلُون: ي، ر، م، ل، و، ن

exercises.prompt: الإدغام هو إدخال حرف _____ في حرف متحرك
exercises.promptEn: Assimilation is inserting a _____ letter into a voweled letter

exercises.prompt: الإدغام _____ يكون الحرف الأول ساكناً أصلاً
exercises.promptEn: The _____ assimilation has the first letter originally vowelless

exercises.prompt: الإدغام _____ يكون الحرف الأول متحركاً فيُسَكَّن
exercises.promptEn: The _____ assimilation has the first letter voweled, then made silent

exercises.prompt: حروف (يَرْمَلُون) هي: ي، ر، م، ل، _____، ن
exercises.promptEn: The letters of (yarmaloon) are: ya, ra, mim, lam, _____, nun

exercises.answer: assimilation (merging two letters into one doubled letter)

exercises.prompt: The process where a vowelless letter merges into the following letter
Letters that share the same articulation point
